data.title: Dive into anything
data.text:
Hi,

My long-term aspirations are in quantitative finance, specifically more trading and analysis rather than development. Though admittedly I only became interested in the field late last year because it seemed to be much more of a challenge than other forms of financial trading and analysis. Also, seems to be where things are headed long-term.

Apologies if similar questions have been asked and answered as nauseam. I've just graduated from the Open University here in the UK with a BA (Hons) in Politics, Philosophy and Economics. Terrible degree to get into quant finance of course.

I've enrolled on to the CFA. I've been self-learning further maths (my aim is to self-learn undergraduate level and eventually postgraduate level since I've got an A-Level/High school), econometrics (which I have a good grasp of since I specialised in Economics in my degree), data science and stats with help. I've also been learning python for a few months now, and am hoping to then move on to C++ soon. I hope to then do a few of my own side-projects and hopefully collaborate on some.

I currently work in the financial services industry but more in wealth management and to some extent asset management.

I will be doing an MSc starting in 2021, but I have no idea which is more relevant and effective to break into the industry and to learn the relevant knowledge. I have a choice between two, since I can only do distance learning:

MSc Mathematical Finance at University of York:

https://www.york.ac.uk/study/postgraduate-taught/courses/msc-mathematical-finance-online/

Or

MSc Statistics at University of Sheffield:

https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/maths/prospectivepg/taughtpg/statistics

I can't do the MSc Statistics with Financial Mathematics at Sheffield because I don't have an undergraduate in maths.

My questions are: which MSc is better for knowledge and to break in to the industry given my background? Also, is there anything else I can do to boost my chances to break into the industry or is it just a matter of learning? (Quantopian is awesome)

Apologies for the long post, and I appreciate it!
